ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the Cradle Paradox in Africa and how science has been used and abused in colonized and previously colonized nations.
Introspection and deep analysis skills. I learned to question the status quo and observe evolution from a decolonized perspective.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think this course covers very interesting subject matter, and I like the different lenses that are used to look at the study of anthropology in Africa and how it can be alienating to African peoples. The structure of this course was challenging for facilitating student learning because the readings, and how we were prompted to engage with them, did not facilitate much seminar-like discussion. Additionally, while the classes where we had a sort of hybrid lecture seminar format improved upon this, the lectures did not go very far beyond the readings. I think if maybe there were broad overarching questions that guided discussion and/or class discussion was intermixed with lecture (pausing to discuss in small groups or as a class within the lecture) that might better serve this course.
the strengths are attention to detail, emphasis on centering the African experience. The weakness would be that it was content heavy

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would not recommend this course as it is currently structured. Unfortunately, I think that the format of this course left most students disengaged with the work and information. I also think that, while the readings were very interesting and the subject matter important for both anthropology and African studies, the class itself did little to engage us beyond these readings. The course as a whole felt disjointed and unorganized in a way that left me wondering what I had learned.
